title: Dubai uses number plate scanners to detect people breaking lockdown
description: Cameras used to catch drivers breaking the speed limit will now analyse drivers’ license plates and determine whether they are deemed essential workers, according to Gulf News

title: The UAE uses smart helmets to detect fevers
description: According to the government website, the smart helmet is equipped with a thermal camera which can help the authorities in detecting infected people from a safe distance, it can create and read QR codes and can also recognise vehicle licence plate numbers. Equipped with facial recognition technology, the helmet can also display the subject’s name on the Augmented Reality visor, as well as their medical history.The smart helmets scan the temperatures of up to 200 people a minute and can apparently measure temperatures from five metres (16 ft) away, triggering an alert if someone with a fever is detected.

title: CuidAr: Argentina's symptom checker and information app
description: Described by the Ministry of Health as a symptom self-assessment app. Also a health code app?

involved_organisations: The Ministry of Telecommunications and Information Technology
title: Corona.asan.gov.af: Afghan symptom checker website
description: Unclear why the website was taken down or if there is an alternative.

title: Two UAE cities use drones to enforce lockdown orders
description: UAE police in Sharjah and Dubai have been using drones equipped with loudspeakers to order people to stay home.

notes.text: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-LNl1JR3I6I&ab_channel=VOANews

title: Argentinian quarantine app in Rosario and Sante Fe
description: The app will be installed by the province's Criminal Investigation Agency to track those who are under criminal investigation for violating quarantine. The app will send reports to the the MPA investigation office and coordinated by the Attorney General's Office. Individuals will be required to sign a document acknowledging that they have been informed that breaking quarantine will make them liable to a sentence of six months to two years in prison, which will also apply if the individual deletes or uninstalls the app or prevents it from operating.

title: Co-Track: Argentinian contact tracing app
description: Currently being used officially in Misiones, Mendoza and Santiago del Estero, according to the Co-Track website.
data_storage_details: According to the CoTrack website: Your GPS information is stored on your phone, so when you decide to delete the application they will be deleted as well. You can ask us at baja@cotrack.social to delete all your other records from our databases, indicating the phone number, gender, and dates of birth that you uploaded.

related_legislations.details: According to Section 5 (3) of the Epidemic Act, at the request of a district administrative authority, all persons, such as in particular doctors, laboratories, employers, family members and staff from community facilities, who could contribute to the surveys, are obliged to provide information. Even if such a transmission of data (telephone number) by the Red Cross to the responsible district administrative authority is not intended and is also not technically implemented, we could be forced to provide your telephone number. Should such a case occur, the legal basis is Art 6 Paragraph 1 lit c in conjunction with Art. 9 Paragraph 2 lit i GDPR.

title: Stopp Corona: Austrian contact tracing app
description: Ugraded to be in line with Google and Apple approach
data_storage_details: According to the Red Cross website: We have designed the app to record as little date as possible. It is in our interest, that we are not able to identify you as long as you do not report an infection with the Corona virus. Only when you report an infection, we will record your phone number for maximum 30 days, to prevent misuse. Other than that, we will only know a unique user ID (UUID) which is not connected to any other data points. With the provided information it is not possible for us to find out who you are.

title: Palantir software used by agencies in Austria
description: Bloomberg reported "agencies" in Austria - among other countries - were using Palantir software
data_storage_details: Unclear

title: Austria's largest telecoms company provides location data to government
description: A1 , the largest telecommunications company in Austria, has provided the government with aggregated and anonymized "movement profiles" of all mobile phone users in the country. A1's data is being anlyzed by data firm Invenium that can provide details about how people are moving around on a "municipality basis".
data_storage_details: Data is aggregated and anonymised

related_legislations.details: Although the country's data protection agency opposes publishing the personal details of those who have not breached the isolation order, as one municipality did, the agency considers it's not illegal to publish the personal details of those who have breached the order, and deems doing so proportionate to the threat and in the public interest.

involved_organisations: Local Self-Government of the Republika Srpska
title: Naming and shaming for quarantine enforcement in Bosnia
description: In the Republic of Srpska, the names and hometowns of the first 30 people who broke quarantine were published on March 23. The individuals were also fined.
data_storage_details: The list of names is still free to read online

title: Belgian telecoms companies share location data
description: Proximus, Telenet and Orange have been providing data to Belgium’s "Data taskforce against corona".

title: Drone enforces lockdown in Brussels
description: Police in Brussels and in part of Limburg deployed drones to help enforce lockdown measurements and the ban on gatherings of more than two people.

title: Brazilian start up helping regional governments assess lockdown compliance
description: InLoco is delivering reports to authorities across the country with data that includes rankings of social distancing by neighborhood, percentages of people who remained at home in individual neighborhoods as well as mobility patterns around where people go when they leave their homes. Users are geotracked through a location map that doesn't use GPS or beacons which InLoco claims to be 30 times more accurate than GPS.

notes.text: Users are geotracked through a location map that doesn't use GPS or beacons, which InLoco claims to be 30 times more accurate than GPS.

title: Palantir software used by agencies in Canada
description: Bloomberg reported agencies in Canada were using Palantir’s software to plan their virus response.
data_storage_details: Unclear

title: BeAware: Contact tracing and tracking bracelets
description: Contact tracing and home quarantine app. The app notifies users if they have come into contact with an infected person or if they are approaching a location where there are infections. Working in tandem with the electronic bracelet, the app also makes sure people who have been ordered to self-quarantine remain in their location. Ministry of Health officials may randomly send picture requests to which self-isolating individuals must respond with a photo that clearly shows their face and bracelet. An alert is also sent to the monitoring station if the wearer moves further than 15 metres away from their phone.
enforcement_details: According to Bahrain’s Information & eGovernment Authority (iGA), violators will face legal penalties, potentially being sentenced to imprisonment for a period of not less than three months, as well as a fine between BD 1,000 ($2,660) and BD 10,000 ($26,595), or either one of the two penalties. Attempting to remove or tamper with the bracelet will also be considered a violation, the ministry said in a statement.

title: Montreal "report a situation" website
description: Montreal police have launched an online system to enable residents to report suspicious activity such as group gatherings after police officers noticed significant crowding in certain areas of the city. Montreal residents can use online reporting system to report social gatherings, non-essentials stores that are open and soccer matches in the park.

related_legislations.details: The protections have not yet been put into legislation, however, as Australia's Parliament is not sitting regularly.

title: Covid-Safe: Australian coronavirus contact tracing app
description:
According to the government website: "COVIDSafe stores contacts on the phone for 21 days. Nobody can access the encrypted information on your phone, including you. If you test positive for COVID-19, a state or territory health official will ask you to consent to upload your digital handshake information to the National COVIDSafe Data Store.

Wikipedia: COVIDSafe is a digital contact tracing app announced by the Australian Government on 14 April 2020 to help combat the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The app is based on the BlueTrace protocol developed by the Singaporean Government, and was first released on 26 April 2020. (source, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_apps#List_of_countries_with_official_contact_tracing_apps)

notes.text: Robert said when the pandemic was over the app could be deleted and the data would not be retained.

enforcement_details: Voluntary although the government said it would not rule out making it mandatory
data_storage_details: “Only state health authorities" can access the data uploaded to the CovidSafe data store. State and territory health officials must undertake system training before they can access the National COVIDSafe Data Store.

title: Swiss contact tracing app: SwissCovid
description: The SwissCovid app for mobile phones (Android/iPhone) is helping to contain the coronavirus. It complements the conventional contact tracing carried out by cantonal authorities to track new infections.

notes.text: First version App Store Jun 2nd

data_storage_details: IDS exchanged between phones remain stored on the mobile phones for 14 days and are subsequently deleted automatically.

title: Swisscom alert governments to group gatherings
description: To enforce social distancing, telecom company Swisscom will alert the government when more than 20 phones are located in a 100-square-meter area.
data_storage_details: Cell Tower Data

title: Chinese lockdown enforcement drones
description: Places in China have been using drones equipped with loudspeakers to enforce lockdown measures, telling people to wash their hands and return home.

notes.text: reported Jan 31

title: Corona-Warn-App: Germany's national contact tracing app
description:
The Corona-Warn-App helps to determine whether one has had any contact with an infected person which could result in a risk of catching the virus. 
-
Germany's data protection commissioner, Ulrich Kelber, said he was concerned by "the requirement for many users to call a hotline to confirm a positive Covid-19 test, or to request help with using the app, thus compromising their anonymity.
data_storage_details:
Decentralised, Apple-Google model
According to government: All data – for example on encounters with other people using the app – is encrypted and stored exclusively on your own smartphone

title: DELETE WeChat: China's health code app
description: Opaque health code system. Variations in different regions.
enforcement_details: Green health codes are required in some cities to board public transport, enter neighbourhoods or residential buidlings
data_storage_details: Unclear

title: Switzerland "in talks" about joining Palantir's virus program
description: The Swiss Federal Office of Public Health Switzerland is in talks with Palantir, which is making a version of its "Foundry" data-mining software available for free to governments and international organisations involved in the Covid-19 response

title: Germany region North Rhine-Westphalia  signs a contract with Palantir
description: The German region North Rhine-Westphalia signed a 14 million euro deal to use Palantir's data-mining software, according to Bloomberg. When a nation or company buys access to Palantir, it can use the data analytics software to pull far-flung digital information into a single repository and mine it for patterns. Palantir is also seeking a contract at a national level but talks have apparently stalled.

notes.text: Palantir is notoriously secretive

title: Corona-Datenspende: German health app
description: Germany's Robert Koch Institute has asked people to “donate” the data collected by their fitness armband or smartwatch in order for scientists to monitor signs of the coronavirus

notes.text: Reported April 7

data_storage_details: The app does not store "personal information" but assigns user IDs in order to store health data.

related_legislations.details: According to Telekom, the process for data transfer was developed together with the data protection authorities and approved by the Federal Data Protection Officer in 2015.

title: German telecoms company shares location data
description: The RKI (Germany's public health institute) wants to understand flows of movement: Anonymous location data provided by Telekom for millions of German mobile phone users should show whether lockdown measures are effective.

title: Palantir software used by agencies in Spain
description: A Bloomberg report mentioned Palantir working with Spain

related_legislations.details: Supposedly this app will follow Spain's and EU privacy legislation, but not further details have been released so far. It is not linked to the national state of emergency in Spain.

involved_organisations: State digital and artificial intelligence unit.
title: Radar Covid App: Spain’s contact tracing app being rolled out across the country
description: As of August 27, the app is functioning in seven Spanish regions: Andalusia, Cantabria, Extremadura, Castilla y León and the Canary and Balearic Islands. Because each region is in charge of its own healthcare, the central government can only recommend its use.

notes.text: Technically supposed to launch on September 15

data_storage_details: Decentralised, Google-Apple

title: Finnish government signed a “monitoring agreement” with telco Telia
description: Swedish telco Telia has given anonymized phone location data to the Finnish government for analysis of user movement in the country. Telia said in a press release that it had begun "a custom-made location tracking [service] for the government during the state of emergency".

title: Lockdown enforcement drones in Spain
description: In Madrid, police use drones to tell people to go home

title: France "in talks" about joining Palantir's virus program
description: Paris hospitals in talks with Palantir, which is making a version of its "Foundry" data-mining software available for free to governments and international organisations involved in the Covid-19 response.

notes.text: Palantir is notoriously secretive

title: Palantir software used by agencies in Greece
description: Bloomberg reported "a dozen" governments joined the US and UK in adopting Palantir software to fight the virus. They include agencies in Austria, Canada, Greece and Spain.

title: Nice has been using drones to enforce lockdowns
description: A drone has been flying over Nice to enforce lockdown measures. Through its loudspeaker, it repeats two prerecorded messages: "Travel is prohibited except for exceptions" and "respect the safety distances please".

title: DELETE: Orange discussing contact tracing partnership with Apple in France
description: Orange is in discussions with Apple over developing France’s smartphone app for tracing people who are at risk of coronavirus infection, CEO Stephane Richard said on Thursday.

notes.text: Should be ready by the end of May

title: Israeli permit app for Palestinians
description: Israeli news reports that Palestinians seeking to verify whether their permits to remain in Israel are still valid have been instructed to download an app that enables the military access to their cellphones’ location, notifications, files and the device's camera. To install the app, users need to approve the following terms: "We may make use of the information we collect for any purpose, including for security purposes. "You agree and declare that you know that all the information you are asked to provide is not required by law or defense regulations, and it is provided of your own free will, so that we can make use of it as we see fit. In addition, you consent that we may store the information you have provided to us in our databases based on our considerations".
enforcement_details: The app is not mandatory but because the admin offices are closed, West Bank Palestinians must download the program to monitor their permit’s validity.

title: Hong Kong quarantine enforcement wristbands
description: Hong Kong issues tracking wristbands to people under compulsory home quarantine. The wristbands are linked to a mandatory smartphone app that shares its location with the government via messaging apps WeChat or WhatsApp. People returning from abroad report being asked to fill out a form which suggests passengers have the option of sharing their location with the government via messaging platforms, like WeChat and WhatsApp, or by agreeing to wearing an electronic wristband. However it is unclear whether messaging apps are an option for Hong Kong residents, one person told CNBC they were only able to wear the wristbands.
enforcement_details: A person who contravenes or knowingly gives false information to Department of Health is liable on conviction to a $5000 HKD ($644) fine and to imprisonment for 6 months," according to a handout given to passengers and which was obtained by CNBC.

involved_organisations: the State-Owned Enterprises Ministry and the National Disaster Management Agency
title: PeduliLindungi: Indonesian contact tracing app
description: The app PeduliLindungi cross references the data stored on its users’ mobile devices through Bluetooth connection. When a user is in the vicinity of another user whose data has been uploaded to PeduliLindungi, the app enables an anonymous exchange of identities, according to its official website.
data_storage_details: According to the government, data is encrypted and will not be disclosed to any other party. Data can only be accessed if a person is "likely to have been infected with COVID-19" and "requires immediate medical attention".

title: Israeli police use drones to enforce lockdown
description: Israeli police in the city of Naharia were using drones to patrol the beachfront area and enforce lockdown restrictions.

title: Israel's Shin Bet contact tracing system
description: The controversial tracking system - lead by internal security agency Shin Bet - uses a database called "The Tool" which collects data from cellular providers and phone companies in Israel. This data includes location as well as call, text and internet history metadata.

title: Israel uses AI to flag high-risk COVID patients
description: One of Israel’s largest health maintenance organizations is using artificial intelligence to help identify which of the 2.4 million people it covers are most at risk of severe covid-19 complications. To make its predictions, the system draws on a range of medical data, including a person’s age, BMI, health conditions such as heart disease or diabetes, and previous history of hospital admissions. The AI can trawl through a vast number of records and spot at-risk individuals who might have been missed otherwise.

title: The Shield: Israeli contact tracing app
description: The app was first launched using GPS but a new upgrade now means it also uses Bluetooth to carry out contact tracing.
data_storage_details: Decentralised

title: TrackVirus: Israeli contact tracing app
description: Israeli contact tracing app that also visualises health ministry data to map infections. The information the developers stress is anonymized and is not uploaded to the cloud and the app does not prompt for any form of identification though users do grant geolocation permissions for their smartphones.
data_storage_details: Location history is only stored on the user's device.

title: Indian factory to introduce social distancing AI
description: Samarth Diamond plans to deploy AI from Glimpse Analytics as soon as its polishing factory re-opens in Gujarat, India

notes.text: Reported April 27

title: COVID Alerting Tracking System: Indian state uses telecom location data to enforce quarantine
description: Andhra Pradesh is tracking people who have received quarantine orders, using telecoms data, alerting district authorities if they travel 100-metres from the location where they are supposed to be isolating.

title: Notorious NSO Group developing covid tracker app called Fleming
description:
Around 12 countries are testing NSO technology which "analyzes data" to map people’s movements to identify who they’ve come in contact with. The software takes two weeks of mobile-phone tracking information from the infected person then matches with location data collected by national mobile phone companies that pinpoints citizens who were in the patient’s vicinity for more than 15 minutes and are vulnerable to contagion.

Fleming features an advanced mapping tool that identifies the spread of the virus in real time, empowering health and government decision-makers. By utilising the Fleming system, these decision-makers can more effectively deploy resources, including critical supplies and medical personnel, and implement public health protocols that help contain the spread. In addition, Fleming is helping officials in developing strategies to reopen economies in regions where the pandemic no longer poses a serious health threat. The technology anonymises all data inputted by the operator, which adds an additional layer of privacy and security. Fleming is already being operated by countries around the world as health officials work to stop the spread of COVID-19 and keep citizens safe and healthy.

How long has it been in deployment and where?
Immediately upon the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, NSO – which specialises in developing life-saving technology solutions – recruited the best minds internally, alongside epidemiologists and other experts. NSO was able to quickly develop an innovative system to help eradicate the spread of the pandemic. Fleming was developed in Israel, NSO’s main development centre.

title: Aarogya Setu: India launches COVID-19 tracker app
description: Using a phone's Bluetooth and location data, Aarogya Setu lets users know if they have been near a person with Covid-19 by scanning a database of known cases of infection. A new feature, introduced in August, allows employers to check their staff’s health status.
data_storage_details: Lack of clarity on who can access the data and how long it will stay on government databases.

title: Indian state of Maharashtra quarantine app
description: A platform for quarantine tracking. The app uses GPS data collected from people’s smartphones to create a virtual perimeter around their homes. If users move beyond their permitted radius, the app notifies local authorities.
enforcement_details: If users move beyond their permitted radius, the app notifies local authorities.

notes.text: Only citizens advised by the health officials will be allowed to use the MahaKavach app

title: AC19: Google removes Iran's official COVID-19 detection app from the Play Store.
description:
After it's release, Iran's Health Ministry sent a mass SMS message to all Iranians urging them to install the app to check potential COVID-19 symptoms. The app would let users register using their phone number and then ask Iranians to answer a series of questions related to coronavirus symptoms. The idea was to let Iranians determine if they had severe symptoms, in order to prevent citizens from needlessly flooding local hospitals.

According to ZDNet: A Google spokesperson did not respond to a request for comment on the reasons the app was removed; however, sources familiar with Play Store policies told ZDNet the app was most likely taken down because of its misleading claims -- namely that it could detect COVID-19 infections, something that is impossible through an app.

notes.text: https://www.zdnet.com/article/spying-concerns-raised-over-irans-official-covid-19-detection-app/

title: Lombardy's AllertaLOM app
description: This is an information app that includes a function called “CercaCovid survey”.

title: Kenya Phone Tracking of people in quarantine
description: The authorities in Kenya have been tracking mobile phones of people suspected to have Covid-19 as a way of enforcing a 14-day mandatory isolation period, government spokesman Cyrus Oguna told the BBC.
data_storage_details: Unclear

title: Kazahk city uses video surveillance to enforce quarantine
description: For the city of Almaty the ministry of the interior relies on video surveillance technology called Sergek, produced by the local telecommunications firm Korkem Telecom to find people who break quarantine.

title: Aggregated Location Tracking in Italy
description: In Italy, mobile carriers Telecom Italia, Vodafone and WindTre have offered authorities aggregated data to monitor people’s movements.

title: Liechtenstein's biometric wristbands
description: Liechtenstein is piloting a programme to fit its citizens with biometric bracelets in a new drive to track the emergence of potential cases of Covid-19 in real time. One in 20 Liechtensteiners have been offered the bracelets, which will send data on vital bodily metrics including skin temperature, breathing rate and heart rate back to a Swiss laboratory for analysis.

related_legislations.details: Apparently, in line with data protection laws

title: StopKorona: North Macedonian contact tracing app
description:
The Western Balkans’ first contact-tracing app was donated to the Macedonian authorities by the company Nextsense, which says the app was downloaded more than 5,000 times on its first day.

Wikipedia: The government launched "StopKorona!" on April 13, 2020, becoming the first country in the Western Balkans to launch a COVID-19 tracing app. The Bluetooth-based app traces exposure with potentially infected persons and is designed to help healthcare authorities provide a fast response. The app was developed and donated by Skopje-based Software company Nextsense. To comply with laws on data protection, the app does not use the users' locations nor personal information. The users' mobile phone numbers are the only user-related data, stored on servers managed by the Ministry of Health (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_apps#List_of_countries_with_official_contact_tracing_apps)
data_storage_details: According to the app's website: “Your only data stored by the Ministry of Health is your mobile phone number.”

title: Kuwait enforcement drones
description: Kuwait used drones to broadcast messages in multiple languages urging people to return to their homes.

title: Omani authorities use drone to enforce lockdown
description: In Oman, authorities have used drones to reduce gatherings in public places in the capital Muscat.

related_legislations.details: A new law mandates that the information be used only for the pandemic, and that it be deleted every 30 days.

title: Norwegian halts Smittestop app
description: On June 12, Norway's data protection watchdog said the country's contact tracing app posed a dispproportionate threat to privacy by continuously uploading its users' location to a central server. On June 15, the Norwegian Institute of Public Health (FHI) said it will stop uploading data and delete user data "as soon as possible.

notes.text:
It was launched at April 26th 2020, but pullen on June 26. A new version was probably launched again in December 2020, but I'm not sure.
Dimitri

data_storage_details: Location data is sent to central servers that can be accessed by government health authorities. You can delete your personal information at any time by using the delete functionality in the app, or you can delete the app. You can also choose whether to turn the logging features on or off.

title: SmartAstana: Kazahkstan quarantine enforcement app
description: The Kazakhstani ministry of health requires the 8,000 or so Kazakhstani citizens currently under quarantine to use the SmartAstana tracking app

title: Shaming quarantine breakers in Paraguay
description: Police officers in Paraguay posted videos of themselves on social media, threatening people who broke quarantine with a taser, forcing them to do star jumps and making them repeat ‘I won’t leave my house again, officer’ while lying face down on the floor. Videos uploaded to Twitter here: https://twitter.com/npyoficial/status/1242477222369193991

title: Home Quarantine (Kwarantanna domowa): Poland’s Home Quarantine App
description: The Home Quarantine app requires users to submit selfies to prove that they are complying with quarantine requirements. Geolocation and facial recognition confirm that they are adhering to the rules.
enforcement_details: Mandatory, although alternatives provided included police visits
data_storage_details: All the data will stay with the government for six years

title: Qatari drones used for lockdown enforcement
description: Qatar announced it was carrying out a drone-based "awareness drive" targeting foreign workers, after images of what appeared to be foreign nationals praying on the roof of apartment buildings in a Doha suburb the previous weekend were published by local media.

title: Moscow plans geo-location tracking for tourists
description: According to the Moscow Times, “Moscow is planning to track foreign tourists' movements through smartphone geolocation for coronavirus prevention after Russia reopens its national borders".

title: Drones used in Kigali to enforce lockdown
description: In Kigali, police stop cars and pedestrians to ask why they are out, while two drones fly above them – one broadcasting instructions and the other "monitoring movements".

notes.text: Reported April 17

title: Saudi drones deployed to detect fevers
description: In Saudi Arabia, municipal authorities used drones to measure body temperatures of shoppers in Buraidah. The drones were fitted with artificial intelligence-enabled thermal cameras.

notes.text: Reported late March

title: Sweden aggregated anonymized location tracking
description: Sweden is using location data from a local telecom company to assess country-wide movements. "The data can also be used as a basis for making decisions on possible measures, and to evaluate the effect of measures already taken, such as recommendations to keep distances and to avoid unnecessary travel," the health authority says.

title: ProteGo Safe: Polish contact tracing and self-assessment app
description: The app has two functions: the self-monitoring modules and the contact tracing function.
data_storage_details: Decentralised

title: TraceTogether: Singapore's contact tracing app
description: If two people who have downloaded the app spend at least 30 minutes within 2 metres of each other, their phones "shake hands", exchanging a unique code that is stored on their phone for 21 days. If one of them becomes infected, disease detectives can use these codes to quickly identify who else might be at risk.
data_storage_details: According to the government website: "Data about devices near you is stored securely on your device, and will only be shared with MOH if you test positive for COVID-19, for the sole purpose of contact tracing. The anonymised Bluetooth data stored on your device after 25 days is automatically deleted.

title: Singapore's quarantine enforcement texts
description: In Singapore, the government uses text messages to contact people, who must click on a link to prove they are at home.

involved_organisations: Thailand National Broadcasting and Telecommunications Commission (NBTC)
Thailand National Science and Technology Development Agency (NSTDA).
title: AOT Airport App: Thailand's application for inbound travellers
description: The app must be installed before passing through immigration points for those who have travelled to, or returned from, contagious areas outside Thailand. This application will track tourists and returnees by using the mobile phone location data and will notify the NBTC, and the mobile phone service provider, if the user is infected after entry into Thailand.

notes.text: https://www.bangkokpost.com/tech/1876684/arrivals-to-provide-data-via-aot-app

data_storage_details: According to Bangkok Post: The system will keep travellers’ information for 14 days after arrival and is linked with the Immigration Police and the DDC, said NBTC secretary-general Takorn Tantasith.

title: MorChana: Thailand contact tracing app
description: There are reports that the app carries out contact tracing but it seems mostly to be a health monitoring app. According to the Bangkok Post: “After answering health assessment questions they will receive risk level results shown in four colours: green (lowest risk), yellow (low risk), orange (risky) and red (high risk).”
data_storage_details: According to the Bangkok Post: "Data will be held until 30 days after the Covid-19 pandemic and the repeal of the Emergency Decree and then be "erased, destroyed or anonymised”.

title: Tunisia's police robots
description: A police robot has been deployed to patrol areas of Tunisia's capital, Tunis, to ensure people are observing lockdown. If it sees anyone walking in the largely deserted streets, it approaches them and asks why they are out. They must then show their ID and other papers to the robot's camera, so officers controlling it can check them. The four-wheeled robots called PGuards have a thermal-imaging camera and Lidar (light detection and ranging) technology which works like radar but uses light instead of radio waves.

title: Korona Önlem: Turkish app
description: Korona Önlem, literally translated as Corona Prevention, is an information and symptom checker app.

title: ZostanZdravy: Slovak contact tracing app
description: Contact tracing app developed by "experts" and volunteers, not endorsed by government
data_storage_details: Centralised

title: Taiwan's "electronic fence" quarantine tracking system
description: If a quarantined person leaves their home or turns off their phone, their location data alerts local police who will visit or get in touch. The system monitors phone signals to alert police and local officials if those in home quarantine move away from their address or turn off their phones. Taiwan's cyber security head said authorities will contact or visit those who trigger an alert within 15 minutes. Officials also call twice a day to ensure people don’t avoid tracking by leaving their phones at home.

involved_organisations: Ministry of Digital Transformation of Ukraine
title: Ukraine’s “Diy Vdoma” (“Act at Home”) quarantine app
description: According to Human Rights Watch: “Once a person downloads the Act at Home app, they have 24 hours to reach their stated address before activating the app, which begins the 14-day self-isolation period at that address. During that period, they receive prompts at random times, and must respond within 15 minutes with a selfie, which will be verified along with the location where the photo was taken. If they do not respond within 15 minutes, they receive several warning messages, and if they fail to respond, a police officer may come, and they may face administrative or even criminal charges if they are not found at home. As of June 15, 40,000 Ukrainians had downloaded the app.”
enforcement_details: Mandatory, although if people don’t want to use the app, they can spend quarantine in a government facility

title: Turkey's Pandemic Isolation Tracking Project
description: Turkey has launched a project for reducing the spread of the novel coronavirus by using location data from patients’ mobile devices. All telecommunication companies must share the location and contact information of patients who tested positive for covid-19. If the patient does not respect quarantine, he/she will receive an automatic alert and may face sanctions.

notes.text: Until the risk of the virus ends.

data_storage_details: According to Reuters, The directorate said Turkey’s government will ensure that the personal data collected will not be used for any other aim.

title: V-COVID: VST Enterprises creates digital healthcare passport
description: The British biometric start-up has created "a digital passport in a scannable app" with VCode which enables "secure identification and ID, geo location and geo fencing, asset tracking, authentication and permission-based authorizations".

title: British health service uses tech giants like Palantir to plan coronavirus response
description: The NHS will work with Amazon, Microsoft, Panlantir and Faculty to model and predict where ventilators, hospital beds and medical staff will be needed most
data_storage_details: Anonymized data that will be deleted "once the crisis is over

title: UK police use drones for rural lockdown enforcement
description: Police in the British region of Derbyshire filmed hikers before releasing the drone footage online in an attempt to publicly shame those breaking lockdown orders.

title: NHS Covid 19 English and Welsh contact tracing app
description: Techcrunch: [In September,] The Times reports that a repackaged version of the app will only provide users with information about infection levels in their local area. The newspaper also suggests the app will let users provide personal data in order to calculate a personal risk score.

notes.text: Britain wants "further improvements to the Google-Apple platform" so the app might not be launched for months

data_storage_details: Decentralised

title: Thermal cameras and facial recognition installed at Bristol (UK) airport
description: Bristol airport in the UK has installed a system which combines facial recognition system with thermal cameras to quickly spot people with high temperatures.

involved_organisations: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
An ad hoc coalition of tech companies and data providers
title: Adtech data used to assess lockdown compliance in the US
description: The CDC is using location data from adtech firms to understand Americans' lockdown compliance. The goal is to create a portal that federal, state, and local officials can use to study geolocation from up to 500 US cities and see which retail establishments, parks, and other public spaces continue to draw crowds as well as show general levels of compliance with lockdown orders
data_storage_details: The data is stripped of identifying information like the name of a phone’s owner, according to WSJ.

title: Connecticut town plans fever-detecting drones
description: A Connecticut police department said it plans to begin testing a "pandemic drone" that could detect whether a person 190 feet away has a fever or is coughing. The drone manufacturer, Draganfly, said in a statement that the technology can detect fever, coughing, sneezing and heart and respiratory rates, and that Westport police plan to use it to protect those considered high-risk, such as senior citizens, and monitor people gathering in crowds, including to see if they are maintaining social distancing.
enforcement_details: A police spokesman said that during the testing phase of the program no action will be taken if the drone shows that a person has a fever or is coughing. The focus, for now, is to evaluate information from the drone, Lieutenant Anthony Prezioso said.
data_storage_details: Unclear

title: New Jersey drones enforce social distancing
description: In Elizabeth, New Jersey, Mayor Chris Bollwage will be using drones to remind residents who are breaking social distancing rules of the penalties they could suffer if they do not cease immediately. The police department will use a fleet of five DJI Mavic 2 UAV drones on loan from manufacturer DJI to patrol Elizabeth. It will convey an automated message from Bollwage to "stop gathering, disperse, and go home. The police department said that only an automated message will be dispersed to help enforce social distancing. No images or other personal information will be collected.
data_storage_details: No data to be stored

title: Clearview negotiates pandemic role
description: Clearview AI is allegedly negotiating a contact tracing partnership with state agencies to monitor infected people and the individuals with whom they have interacted.

title: Bellevue WA app to track lockdown violators
description: After police in Bellevue, WA were inundated with calls from local residents reporting suspected violations of the state's week-old stay-at-home order, they asked the public to use the MyBellevue app instead, to keep 911 lines open for emergencies.

title: Palantir collaborates with US health agencies
description: The data mining company Palantir is already collaborating with the CDC to help assess where the virus is spreading (or could spread to) and how best to allocate limited resources.

title: Company uses smart thermometers track Covid spread in States
description: Kinsa Health, that has used internet-connected thermometers to predict the spread of the flu, says it is tracking the coronavirus in real time. The company has sold or given away more than a million smart thermometers to households in which two million people reside, and can record fevers almost as soon as consumers experience them.

title: Chicago-based construction firm using AI to enforce social distancing among workers
description: Chicago-based Pepper Construction, which introduced software from SmartVid.io this month to detect workers grouping at an Oracle Corp project in Deerfield, Illinois.

title: San Francisco company developing immunity passports
description: Onfido is working with at least one European government to develop phone-based "immunity passports" for those who have already recovered from COVID-19 and tested positive for antibodies. CEO Husayn Kassai tells Axios that there have been indirect discussions at both the federal and state levels via partners.

title: Michigan shopping centres to use social distancing AI
description: Two Michigan shopping centres owned by RPT Realty will have distancing tracking from RE Insight in two weeks.

title: Care19: North Dakota contact tracing app
description: Care19 traces contacts via GAEN.

notes.text: Later relaunched with GAEN

data_storage_details: An analysis by The New York Times confirmed that the app sends people’s location data to a private server hosted on Microsoft’s cloud platform. Mr. Brookins, the developer, said only he and one other person have access to the server, and health officials can get the data only of people who test positive for the coronavirus and then agree to share it.

title: Aggregated Location Tracking provided by Google
description: Google is using GPS location data from mobile phones to publish online reports showing changes in the number of visitors to public places such as transport hubs, parks, workplaces, homes, pharmacies and grocery stores in 131 countries.

title: South Africa uses telecom data for contact tracing
description: Under lockdown regulations, subject to regular review by a former constitutional court judge, the state has the power to access data from mobile phone companies on the movements of possible coronavirus contacts.

notes.text: The major difference in South Africa is that it is not an opt-in app, as it is in Singapore and Australia," said Livia Dyer, a partner at Bowmans, a South African law firm. "It is reflective of the way mobile phones are used in this country," she said, since the poorest citizens do not have smartphones.

title: Amazon launches artificial intelligence tracking system to enforce social distancing at its offices and warehouses
description: A new system called "Distance Assistant" will see monitors set up in workplaces - highlighting workers who are too close in red circles and those who aren't in green circles. Amazon is also testing a wearable device that lights up and makes an audio alert when workers get too close and the company has also been hiring social distancing ambassadors and guardians. It was previously reported that the company was introducing thermal cameras into its workspaces but it is unclear if this is still happening.

notes.text: Launched in June 2020 according to Amazon blogpost: https://www.aboutamazon.com/news/operations/amazon-introduces-distance-assistant
Open Society Foundations has said the measure is also a scapegoat to avoid unionizing, as workers can't get close to have conversations

title: Belgian port workers to wear buzzing social distancing bracelets
description: Antwerp port said it would be fitting thousands of workers with the devices to test them in May 2020. The “bracelets" apparently vibrate when workers come within ten feet of each other, with the buzz intensifying and warning lights flashing the closer they get.

title: Croatia's digital Andrew chatbot app
description: Andrew is a "digital assistant" from Croatia's Ministry of Health that runs on WhatsApp

title: Croatian drones in Vukovar and other cities in Eastern Slavonia
description: The area of ​​the city of Vukovar and other cities in Eastern Slavonia will be monitored by police drones. The aim is to monitor gatherings with the drones, to which authorities on the ground will respond to.

notes.text: According to N1, "surveillance of drones in eastern Croatia is carried out on the basis of a decision of the Directorate of Civil Protection, in the situation of a coronavirus epidemic."

title: CovTracer: Contact tracing app Cyprus
description: The software is based on the Safepaths project developed at MIT.

notes.text: Launched in March

title: eRouska: Czechia's contact tracing app, also integrated into the smart quarantine system
description: Contact tracing app part of the Smart Quarantine concept of the Ministry of Health of the Czech Republic. After launched, app was updated to incorporate the Google Apple framework.
data_storage_details: Log of meetings is stored internally on phone. If a hygienist contact you, you can send them a list of these meetings. Only authorized employees of the hygiene station have access to the central database.

involved_organisations: Ministry of Social Affairs and Health
title: Ketju: Finnish contact tracing trial
description: Trialled at Vaasa Central Hospital. Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare told The Correspondent the the app was never offered to the government.

title: ProteGo: Poland’s contact tracing app
description: The app plans to show Red when its user has had contact with an infected person, prompting them to contact a doctor and quarantine. But Green means the user is not in an endangered group. They can move around remembering the basic principles of safety and hygiene. For the first two weeks after download, the app will show orange.
data_storage_details: Decentralised

title: Mask.ir: Iran contact tracing app
description: Developed by Sharif University of Technology which also owns or manages(?) the database
data_storage_details: Centralised

title: Drones used in Wexford caravan parks to monitor compliance with movement restrictions
description: Caravan parks in Wexford were under drone surveillance for weeks, as local officials tried to track down tourists who should not be there.

notes.text: First reported Apr. 26th, but references to four weeks earlier

title: Police drones used in Poland to look for people breaking lockdown orders
description: Mariusz Ciarka, spokesman for the police says that checking one park is usually a few dozen minutes of work for a police team. The drone operator can do the same job in tens of seconds.

title: Virusafe: Bulgarian symptom checker and info app
description: Daily symptoms tracker with heatmap feature. Informs users about news and best practices. "Users can also voluntarily share their location to enable institutions to act accordingly, in case of an emergency.”
data_storage_details: Centralised database "owned by health authorities"

title: Danish symptom tracker ‘COVIDmeter’
description: According to Public Health Institute website, “When you sign up for the solution [via sundhed.dk], you need to provide a few background information about yourself such as your age, gender and zip code. When you sign up, you can choose to provide your email address. Then you will receive a reminder email every week with a link to the questionnaire. Then you answer every week questions about whether you have felt sick, whether you have been tested for COVID-19 or have had contact with family, friends or acquaintances with COVID-19.”

notes.text: https://www.ssi.dk/sygdomme-beredskab-og-forskning/sygdomsovervaagning/c/covid19-borgeres-frivillige-rapportering-af-symptomer

title: Smittestop: Denmark’s contact tracing app
description: Denmark released details of Mobile Proximity App, switching from a decentralised design after originally favouring a centralised one
data_storage_details: Decentralised

involved_organisations: Health and Welfare Information Systems Center
title: HOIA: Estonian contact tracing app launches
description: Twelve Estonian companies  and several government institutions have developed a decentralised contact tracing app.
data_storage_details: Decentralised

related_legislations.details: Reuters: Known in Europe for being a staunch defender of privacy rights, the CNIL said that while the technology was well-meaning in its intent, the artificial intelligence empowered surveillance falls short of respecting Europe’s stringent laws on data protection.

title: French city uses cameras to monitor masks and social distancing
description: AI equipped CCTV cameras are being used at Cannes' outdoor markets and on buses. The system can send automatic alerts to police when breaches of the mask and distancing rules are spotted.

notes.text: Datakalab says its algorithms can be incorporated into existing surveillance systems in other public spaces, such as hospitals, stations, airports and shopping centres.

title: Remote monitoring for French University students
description: Ministry of Higher Education published a document which said: "written exams require special remote monitoring which makes it possible to verify the identity of the student and to avoid fraud. They therefore require recourse to remote monitoring services".

notes.text: March 2020
Unclear if any in use

title: Police in Paris using drones to enforce lockdowns
description: A May 18th decision by Conseil d'Estat determined that Paris police grounds all its drones surveillance of demonstrations, after mobilization from civil society entities. Human rights groups said police deployed drones to identify offenders or guide patrols on the ground and by bellowing instructions through loudspeakers.

notes.text: First reported March 24th (https://www.20minutes.fr/paris/2747063-20200324-coronavirus-paris-police-utilise-drones-inciter-habitants-rester-confines)
Court decision: https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=e81fdeeb-b669-456a-a600-b220129e57e7

involved_organisations: Latvian Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
title: Apturi Covid: Latvian contact tracing app
description: A group of Latvian tech and telecom companies aim to develop one of the first contact tracing apps using Google/ Apple's system
data_storage_details: Decentralised

title: COVID-19 Check: Maltese symptom checker website
description: Asks questions to assess risk of being infected, whether you should take a test

title: Portuguese Police deploy drones to enforce lockdown
description: The authorities use drones to "warn" the population in Porto

title: StopCOVID19Cat: Catalonia symptom checker app
data_storage_details: According to the privacy policy, “The data required will be those strictly necessary, appropriate and relevant for the purpose for which they are collected and will be subjected to an automated and anonymized treatment.”
description: The app has a double functionality: it offers users a self-assessment questionnaire and provides authorities with population data to generate heat maps

title: CoronaMadrid: Madrid symptom checker app
data_storage_details: Privacy policy link leads to an error page
description: The CoronaMadrid mobile application allows its users to have practical information on COVID-19, based on a personal self-assessment with the possibility of obtaining recommendations and advice to rationalize and facilitate contact with health authorities at any stage of the conception of the COVID-19 disease

title: World Health Organisation plans to launch a symptom checker app
description: Few details released

title: World Health Organisation plans to launch a contact tracing app
description: The app will ask people about their symptoms and offer guidance on whether they have coronavirus. Other information, such as how to get tested, will be personalized according to the user‚Äôs country.

title: Singapore's Robodog enforces social distancing
description: Singapore authorities are using a robot dog called SPOT to politely broadcast messages to remind joggers and cyclists to stay apart. SPOT is fitted with cameras and analytics tools to estimate the number of people in the park.
data_storage_details: Authorities said the cameras would not be able to track individuals or record personal data.

notes.text: Another robot, in the shape of a small car, has been deployed at a nearby reservoir to warn visitors "not to loiter" and that "gatherings are not allowed".

title: Healthy Together: Utah Contact Tracing App
description: Latest update includes the ability to “connect health passports for participating organizations, schools and businesses”. It does not use the Google Apple API because the website says Bluetooth and GPS together give a more accurate picture.
data_storage_details: Centralised

title: TraceCovid: Abu Dhabi contact tracing app
description: The app is still available via Google and Apple app stores but authorities are now encouraging people in the UAE to download the ALHOSN app instead.
data_storage_details: No personal data collected or stored, according to promotional video.

title: Savitas: Belgian corporate contact tracing system
description:
According to the Brussels Times: In companies that choose to use the "Savitas" system, workers can alert the technology if they have been diagnosed with the new coronavirus (Covid-19) by scanning a QR code on their smartphone. Anyone who has scanned the same QR code around the same time as the person infected will then be alerted the next time they scan, or when they visit the website.
It doesn't seem active anymore

title: Belgian rail tests sensors to keep workers apart during COVID-19
description: According to Reuters: Intelligent cameras will sound a warning if there are too many people in one area, if they do not have face masks or if they get too close to one another

title: BruHealth: Brunei's QR code app
description: Business owners must download the app and register before they are allowed to reopen. App users, including employees and customers, must scan the QR code every time they enter or leave business premises, allowing authorities to track potential carriers of COVID-19. The app generates a five-colour ranking system using Bluetooth and it is also linked to the health ministry’s BruHIMS patient data system and artificial intelligence system so it knows whether the user has visited a doctor.

title: Druk Trace: Bhutan contact tracing app
description: Mandatory app where users scan the QR code every time they enter public places or use public transport. People who don’t have smartphones will be required to provide contact information to be filled in the log files that are to be managed by the respective offices and drivers.

title: Recife (Brazil) uses cell phone location for monitoring lockdown compliance
description: The mayor of Recife said the city is tracking at least 700,000 smartphones to identify where the lockdown rules are being followed. Brazilian startup InLoco develops the geolocation technology, which is normally used by companies from sectors such as retail, to securely target and engage with users without the need to share personal information. Users are geotracked through a location map that doesn't use GPS or beacons, which InLoco claims to be 30 times more accurate than GPS.

title: COVID Alert app: Canada’s national contact tracing app launched
description: App has been adopted by 9 provinces, which means that only users in these provinces can use the app to report a diagnosis, but government still encourages users outside these locations to download the app to be notified if you come into contact with someone from a reporting province or territory and when other app users in your area are able to report a diagnosis.
data_storage_details: Decentralised, Apple-Google model, Identification 'highly improbable' but not impossible, office of privacy commissioner says in September.

title: ABTraceTogether: Alberta's contact tracing app
description: ABTraceTogether is a mobile contact tracing app for the Canadian province of Alberta that helps to let you know if you've been exposed to COVID-19 – or if you've exposed others – while protecting your privacy.
data_storage_details: Personal data is only stored on your phone for 21 days in an encrypted format and it will not be shared with AHS contact tracers without your permission.

title: Swiss government asked Swisscom for data on people's movements
description: Switzerland has asked state-controlled Swisscom for day-old mobile phone data to help judge whether measures to restrict people’s movements and slow the coronavirus’s spread were working, a federal health ministry official said.

title: Hangzhou proposes turning Alipay health code into permanent tracking system
description: In Hangzhou, the government’s propose making the health score system permanent and incorporating more data such as medical records, results of physical examinations and lifestyle choices. In a screenshot of the barcode-based system, a person’s health score can be seen going down because they drank alcohol and smoked cigarettes. Meanwhile, a good amount of sleep plus exercise increases a person’s score.
enforcement_details: Green health codes are required in some cities to board public transport, enter neighbourhoods or residential buidlings

title: CoronApp: Colombia's symptom checker app
description:
App incorporated Bluetrace protocol (like in Singapore). Also serves as mobility passport. At one point, govt. was offering data + calling minutes in exchange for downloads; Educational resources were embedded within the app, so in order to access it, students had to download it. 

After thinking of adopting the Google system, the Colombian government went with BlueTrace Protocol, same system adopted in Singapore, according to Fundación Karisma -

notes.text: Interview with Carolina Botero, Fundación Karisma

title: Maps.cz: Czech Google maps equivalent launches contact tracing feature
description: In mid-March, the country’s largest search engine, Seznam, introduced a coronavirus tracing feature on its geolocation app, Maps.cz. With a user’s permission, it draws on location data to inform people if they have crossed paths with anyone who has tested positive.

notes.text: Launched in mid-March

related_legislations.details: Executive decree signed by Ecuadorian President Lenín Moreno declaring a state of emergency due to public calamity.
related_legislations.title: Executive Decree 1017

title: Ecuador authorizes satellite tracking to improve epidemiological surveillance
description: María Paula Romo, Minister of Government, announced the authorization of satellite tracking of citizens who are included in the epidemiological fence. "Technology allows us to know where a cell phone number is , by GPS in smart phones are already authorized and this is written in the Executive Decree of President Moreno, "said Romo at a virtual press conference from Quito.

notes.text: https://observatoriolegislativocele.com/en/coronavirus-data-protection-and-confidentiality-in-ecuador/

title: Egyptian symptom checker app Sehat Misr
description: The app includes information about the virus, lets users report their symptoms as well as the symptoms of others. It monitors the locations of people with the coronavirus and notifies people if they are in a high-infection area.

title: Ethiopia COVID-19 Monitoring platform
description: Ethiopia’s Information Network Security Agency launched a Covid-19 monitoring platform on March 23 to update the public on the number of Covid-19 cases in the country and to provide information such as directions to the nearest pharmacies, hospitals, and police stations. People who develop symptoms or were in contact with people with confirmed cases can also give information to the ministry of health via the platform. The system also enables users to report illegal or unauthorized activities, such as large public gatherings. It also allows the reporting of people suspected of having symptoms based on an assessment of anothers’ symptoms.

notes.text: Launched on March 23rd, according to Human Rights Watch

related_legislations.details: Decree No. 2020-650 was published on May 29, 2020 setting the definitive legal framework for the implementation of the app

title: StopCovid: French contact tracing app
description: But the French contact tracing app may not be able to connect with others in the EU because it stores data centrally, EU Commission vice-president Margrethe Vestager said.
data_storage_details: Centralised

title: Project Oasis: UK govt launches effort to collect data from third party app-providers to help shape NHS response
description: In a project codenamed "Oasis", the UK's Ministry of Defence innovation unit is merging data from ten British symptom-tracking apps into a central database that is designed to help epidemiologists better understand the behaviour of the virus and its spread across different parts of the country. Data from eight UK-based apps has been collated, with information from a further two being processed. Nine other apps have been asked to supply their data to the Oasis database.

notes.text: According to publication on government website
Announced May 25
More information on government website: https://www.gov.uk/government/news/jhub-support-nhsx-to-securely-share-covid-19-symptom-data

title: Proctoring: British students to have rooms inspected by webcam before online exams
description: Classics students sitting virtual exams over Microsoft teams at Oxford University will start the test with a "camera sweep of the room".

title: Stop Covid: Georgian contact tracing app
description:
Encounters that have a certain intensity in terms of time and proximity are stored locally by both apps in an encrypted form. If someone tests positive for COVID-19, people who may have had contact with the infected person within the last few days will receive a warning.

It doesn't seem it ever got off. There is no mention of the app on government covid websites.
data_storage_details: Decentralised

title: Alerta Guate App: Guatemala coronavirus information app
description: An information app but an investigation by Global Witness found Alerta Guate was sending users’ location information to the developer every few minutes, even when the app was closed.

notes.text: According to Global Witness, the app was developed by In-telligent LLC and funded by Tenlot, a multinational group that manages the country's lottery. The app was then donated to the government.

title: Stop Covid-19: Croatia launches contact tracing app
description: The app will warn users if they have spent more than 10 minutes closer than two meters to a person who wrote positive in the past two weeks.
data_storage_details: According to the government, the app does not collect personal data

title: Israel's AI system to determine likelihood of COVID spread
description: Israeli Defense Minister announced on Twitter the creation of an AI-based score system to determine likelihood of someone spreading COVID-19. Bennett says: "Every citizen at any moment will have a score from 1-10 to the likelihood that he infects people in Corona. Score 3 says you probably aren't contagious; Score 9.5 means you are probably contagious, and then we will ask you to be tested with a PCR throat surface. In his announcement on Twitter, Bennett said the implementation of the system lacked consent from the Health Ministry and approval by the Ombudsman

notes.text: Tweets by Naftali Bennett

title: Israeli police use drones to enforce virus quarantines in Tel Aviv
description: Police are using drones to peek into homes to make sure people are self-isolating. "The drone glides up toward a high-rise until it reaches an apartment window where a woman waves from inside, proving to police that she is self-isolating after testing positive for the coronavirus".

title: C-Radar: Jordanian app
description: An app to report on crowds that do not follow social distancing or people users suspect might be infected with covid-19.

notes.text: Acccording to post on Prime Ministry of Jordan's Facebook page

title: Myride Africa: Kenya's tracing app
description: The app dubbed Myride Africa, which can be used by Personal Service Vehicles and Matatus. "The conductor records the ID number or Phone number of each passenger whenever they board the vehicle. This information can be saved for several days and can be accessed by the government for Contact Tracing when required," said Mbogo.

involved_organisations: State Committee for IT and Communications
title: STOP COVID-19: Kyrgyzstan’s quarantine enforcement app
description: The STOP COVID-19 app, developed by the State Committee for IT and Communications, tracks phone owners known or suspected to have COVID-19… The app is not just a tracking mechanism. It includes a feedback function for users to report on their state of health and even an SOS button in case of a serious deterioration in wellbeing.

notes.text: On Android phones, users install an app. On iPhones, meanwhile, the technology consists just of a bot in the Telegram messaging service.

title: Moroccan police app to monitor lockdown violators
description: Police in Rabat have started using a mobile application to track violators of the kingdom's lockdown and it aims to let police "know which checkpoints a person has passed through, allowing them to trace their movements", officials said.

notes.text: Reported end of April

data_storage_details: According to official news agency MAP, the storage of data "conforms to the rigorous security criteria used by the DGSN in its databases"

title: Wiqaytna: Morocco contact tracing app
description: The app, which will be called "our prevention", was developed by a team of 40 people from different public and private sectors
data_storage_details: Ministry of Interior, Abdelhak Al-Harraq said that all data that will be stored by the application will be disposed of after the pandemic has ended.

title: Mauritian information and work permit app
description: beSafeMoris gives coronavirus information and issues work permits

notes.text: Reported end of March

title: CovCT: contact tracing launched in Malaysia
description: Allows people to input any symptoms and "check in" at locations by scanning a QR code. It requires businesses to get a QR code poster which users can then scan when they visit.

notes.text: Launched in early April

title: COVID Tracer: Contact tracing app New Zealand
description:
The new app, called "NZ COVID Tracer", works by letting users scan QR codes at the businesses, public building and other organisations they visit. It then provides users with a "check-in" history, so they can more easily track their own movements.

On 10 December 2020 the app got an update with the GAEN implementation for Bluetooth contact tracing.
data_storage_details: The app will store location data locally and delete it after 31 days, according to an FAQ on the New Zealand Ministry of Health website.

title: Philippines’ Staysafe.ph app
description: Contact tracing function launched at the start of September
data_storage_details: According to the privacy notice, “We will keep your information for as long as necessary unless you request the deletion of your information, after which these will be securely deleted. However, we may retain your information when required by law.

title: WeTrace: Philippines’ region Cebu launches contact tracing app
description: According to Rappler, on August 5 an executive order (No. 20-C) was passed requiring residents of the province who work in Cebu City and vice versa to apply for a work travel pass through the WeTrace app in order to cross borders.

title: Philippines' ENDCoV health monitoring app
description: The app asks you to answer a survey that identifies your health condition and possible risk and exposure to the virus...As the app’s userbase grows, it can help in contact tracing for the virus by crowdsourcing data from its users, creating a directory of people and places that a prospective patient may have come in contact with.

title: CLEAR: Philippines contact tracing app
description: The developers said the solution put into consideration certain nuances in the Philippine landscape such as the dominance of the prepaid market, access to Internet, and smartphone penetration.

title: CovCT Philippines contact tracing
description: Allows people to input any symptoms and "check in" at locations by scanning a QR code. It requires businesses to get a QR code poster which users can then scan when they visit.

involved_organisations: Department of Science and Technology - Philippine Council for Health Research and Development
title: TanodCOVID: Phillipines' self-assessment tool
description: Self-reporting application for COVID-19 and its symptoms. Data is aggregated and fed into the FASSSTER forecasting tool to predict outcomes for the spread of the coronavirus under different scenarios. According to Rappler,  local government can register on the site to see the aggregated data on virus spread, and not individual data.

involved_organisations: Institute of Systems and Computers Engineering, Technology and Science
title: Stayaway Covid: Portuguese contact tracing app
data_storage_details: Decentralised

title: Ehteraz: Qatar's contact tracing App
description: The app carries out Bluetooth contact tracing. Users are given a health colour code. In some shopping malls, green is mandatory for entry.
data_storage_details: Data collected would be deleted after two months

notes.text: https://thepeninsulaqatar.com/article/03/06/2020/Several-shopping-complexes-in-Qatar-make-Ehteraz-green-status-compulsory-for-entry

title: Rwanda unveils five covid-19 robots
description: Rwanda deploys five robots to screen peoples temperatures (50 to 150 people per minute) and detect if people are wearing masks.

title: ThaiChana Qr code app in Thailand
description: The app requires people to scan a Thai Chana Quick Response (QR) code to check in and check out of restaurants, shops or other businesses.
data_storage_details: According to Bangkok Post: “Thai Chana's website says the app will store the check-in and check-out data for only 60 days, but users will have to take the site's word for it because the statement is not detailed in the terms and conditions.”

title: E7mi: Tunisian contact tracing app
description: Akil Agati, head of the Wizz Labs, said users "will not report themselves infected, to avoid false alarms, and users who have been notified of being in contact with a sick person will also receive a phone call from the ONME so there can be follow-up".
data_storage_details: On a centralized server

title: Corowarner: Turkey contact tracing app
description: We will ask for permission to access the app user’s GPS and bluetooth data to estimate the proximity and duration of an encounter between two users -- one who tested positive for the virus and the other who was at risk of being infected,

title: Ugandan contact tracing app
description: Ugandan firm donates app to Ministry of Health

title: Bluetooth badges for corporate contact tracing
description: Silicon Valley company Juniper Networks Inc plans to equip its about 10,000 employees with work identification badge holders that have a Bluetooth chip that will help to record a worker’s movements and interactions in the office, company vice president Jeff Aaron said in an interview. The system employs Wi-Fi routers and access points from Juniper Network’s unit Mist that will communicate with the Bluetooth chips on the badges. The data collected will help determine which employees need to be tested and isolate after a colleague tests positive for the new coronavirus.

title: Unofficial drone tells New Yorkers to maintain a social distance
description: A frustrated drone enthusiast from Queens, Xavier Arthur, was so angry at people not following guidelines to stay home, he offered what he described as a public service. A loudspeaker on his drone broadcast a message: "This is the Anti-COVID-19 Volunteer Drone Task Force. Please maintain a social distance of at least six feet. Again, please maintain social distancing. Please help stop the spread of this virus, reduce the death toll and save lives. For your own safety and your family's safety, please maintain social distancing.

title: Drone manufacture donates UAVs to US states
description: Chinese drone manufacturer, DJI, gave away 100 UAVs as part of its disaster relief program to 43 agencies in 21 states

notes.text: Announced by DJI: https://enterprise-insights.dji.com/blog/dji-drones-in-covid-19-response-disaster-relief-program

title: US tech companies to develop temperature-monitoring patches for COVID-19
description: A group of tech companies is working on a patch about the size of small bandage that could be worn to monitor for the elevated body temperatures that can sometimes signal the onset of COVID-19. The patch would be powered by a specially designed microchip that will be made in Minnesota at a chip factory operated by SkyWater Technology in collaboration with Ohio-based chip design firm Linear ASICs and New York investment firm Asymmetric Return Capital. The patch is intended to be worn on the skin and to connect wirelessly to a smart phone to monitor a person’s body temperature, the companies said... The companies hope to use artificial intelligence to analyze signals such as the sounds of coughs to identify unique patterns for COVID-19 symptoms.

title: Bluezone: Vietnamese contact tracing
description: SCMP: “According to data from mobile app analytics firm Sensor Tower, until mid-July, Vietnam’s adoption rate of the app was as low as 0.4 per cent of the population, meaning about 390,000 people downloaded it. But since the latest wave later that month, the app has been downloaded over 20 million times, based on official government figures.”
data_storage_details: Decentralised. According to the app, Bluezone stores data on your device only, it does not send such data to the system. It does not collect location data. All Bluezoners are anonymous to others. Only competent health authorities know those who are infected and those who are suspected of infection due to close contact with COVID-19 cases.

title: Gauteng symptom checker app
description: Mpilo app offers coronavirus "self screening" and allows you to "request an ambulance".

notes.text: Repurposed: was launched as a general app in October 2019
Repurposed: was launched as a general app in October 2019, COVID-19 feature added on April 7th, according to Google Play Store records

title: COVID Alert South Africa
description: The developer Co-Pierre Georg told Deutsche Welle: "Every time the code is scanned, you get a so-called geolocation receipt. It's like a note that says: On this day, at this time, you were at this specific place." So far no national governments have shown interest but the developer is in talks with a "major insurance company" and Covi-ID is going to be tested at Cape Town’s OrangeJezicht market.
data_storage_details: Decentralised

title: Zimbabwe's CoronaAlert app
description: Neighbourhood surveillance app: enables users to "report coronavirus cases" to a call centre team

notes.text: Launched in May

title: Corona Kavach: symptom checker app developed by Chhattisgarh (India) government
description: The app is a symptom checker that then warns you if you are approaching someone who has coronavirus

title: Karnataka's quarantine app
description: It's a new mobile app called Quarantine Watch. The government of the southern Indian state of Karnataka is using it to track people it has placed under home quarantine. To see whether people stay put, the app follows users' movements through GPS — and asks them to submit hourly selfies to prove they haven't left the house.

notes.text: Reported March 31st: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/those-in-home-quarantine-in-karnataka-directed-to-send-selfies-every-hour-to-govt/articleshow/74907051.cms

title: Himachal Pradesh's quarantine app, Corona Mukt Himachal
description: To track and monitor people placed under quarantine in the state

title: SMC COVID-19 Tracker: Surat state’s (India) contact tracing app
description:
As of April 2nd, the Municipal Corporation of Surat was using the mobile application SMC COVID-19 Tracker to keep track of 3,600 home-quarantined people in the city. All the 3,600 home-quarantined persons in Surat have been asked to install the mobile application on their smartphones. 

According to India Times: "After installing the app, the user is required to declare his or her current location and travel history. Then every hour the user is required to push a button called "Send Location" to update their whereabouts. If the user is found to have moved out of the house or the specified area, he or she is sent to institutional quarantine."

title: MP COVID RESPONSE APP: India’s Madhya Pradesh symptom checker
description: Information and symptom checker app. After reporting symptoms, the user is contacted by the nearest health center.

title: MahaKavach: Maharashta state’s (India) quarantine app
description: The State government has come up with a mobile application called Mahakavach to trace contacts of COVID-19 positive patients as well those who are home-quarantined. For home-quarantined citizens, the app uses ‘geo fencing’ and ‘selfie attendance.’

notes.text: Reported April 1st: https://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/mumbai/mahakavach-to-ease-contact-tracing-load/article31231782.ece
Only available for Play Store and only to be used by positive COVID-patients.

title: COVA Punjab: self assessment app
description: Self-assessment app; other features added later: audio-video awareness, search of foreign-returned travellers, chatbot, reporting of mass gatherings, marking oneself as home quarantined and geo-fencing of home quarantined.

title: ALHOSN: UAE Contact tracing app
description: The app combines the features of two other UAE apps, STAY HOME and TRACE COVID. The app implements a health code system that combines Bluetooth contact tracing with a red, green or grey QR code that testifies to a person’s COVID-19 risk status. Incoming travellers must also download the Al Hosn app and quarantine for 14 days.
