data_storage_details: According to the ALHOSN website, “the anonymized STI is stored in encrypted form temporarily for 3 weeks on the phone” however no further details are provided.

title: Commswift develops WhatsApp based contact tracing system
description: Visitors to a business scan a QR code which enables them to send a pre-set message to the Commswift system. That message captures their data and allows the business using the system to access a “capacity report”.
data_storage_details: Centralised

title: SocialPass: contract tracing app for Swiss restaurants
description: App for customers and restaurant owners which uses QR codes to establish contact tracing system
data_storage_details: According to the website: ”Personal data resides on the guest’s mobile phone, visit data in a secure cloud accessible by authorized government tracers only. Restaurant management and personnel have no access to it. Contact tracers working for cantons only can access the data, using a secure digital key once they have been informed of the restaurant visit by an infected guest or waiter.

notes.text: First version App Store Jun. 17th

title: VirusRadar: Hungary contact tracing app
description: Patients can decide whether they want to share their data with healthcare authorities as well.
data_storage_details: Decentralised

title: Covid-19 Tracker: Ghana government self assessment app
description: Self assessment app launched by Ghana’s Ministry of Communications

notes.text: https://www.bbc.com/pidgin/tori-52267513

title: COVID Tracker: Irish contact tracing app launched
description: Contact tracing and self assessment app
data_storage_details: Decentralised

title: Madhya Pradesh’s (India) ePass system
description: E-passes necessary for moving around in lockdown

title: In Dubai: AI equipped CCTV to monitor temperatures and social distancing
description: Security cameras in Dubai will be used to detect people’s temperature on the streets, in public places and in shopping centres. The system will alert police to social distancing violations.

title: Bolivia Segura: Coronavirus Bolivia App
description: In Bolivia, the Ministry of Education presented Coronavirus Bolivia , an app that provides information on prevention and care, symptoms, frequently asked questions and emergency numbers, as well as publishing updated official data and communications.

title: Rio de Janeiro police uses drones to alert about agglomerations
description: Rio de Janeiro uses drones with loudspeakers to disperse crowds during pandemic

title: Coronavirus SUS App: Brazil
description: Information and symptom checker app by the Ministry of Health

title: Telecomms companies sharing user data with national statistics agency
description: On April 17th, Brazilian government edited an MP (provisional measure) signed by President Bolsonaro that obliged telecoms companies to share user data (name, phone number, address) with the national statistics agency (IBGE) to enable research to be done during the pandemic (which has impeded researchers from IBGE to do door-to-door research etc). On May 7th, the Supreme Court suspended the measure, voting on manifestations put forward by parties that it violated privacy rights. Even with the suspension, which means the effects of it are suspended, the measure can still be processed in Congress until it expires in August.

notes.text: At the moment its effects are suspended, but it can still be processed in Congress

data_storage_details: The data would be stored in IBGE's (the stats agency) database for the duration of the pandemic. The govt measure explicitly states that after the pandemic is over, the data should be deleted.

title: Chile's CoronApp
description: Information and symptom checker app. Users can also tell the app they will spend their quarantine period and report neighbours' symptoms.
data_storage_details: According to Derechos Digitales: In its privacy, the CoronApp informs that the collected data will be stored outside the country, by Amazon Web Services in Virginia, US, without informing under which security and confidentiality measures this data will be kept

title: Police in Colombia use drones to monitor lockdown compliance
description: Colombia's police have been monitoring lockdown compliance with drones

title: "Medellín me cuida" website
description: Users sign up for monetary assistance, the website checks their symptoms and maps the data to identify/ predict outbreaks.

title: Cali Valle Corona: Colombian self-assessment website and app, with geotracking framework

notes.text: + Interview with Carolina Botero, Fundación Karisma

data_storage_details: Fundación Karisma conducted a sweep-through of the app: "Besides health data, it asks for those registering lots of unnecessary personal data, such as the person's car's license plate. CalivValle Corona activated 35 permissions, including some that have a higher risk to people's privacy: it allows access to external storage devices, detailed and approximate location control - one of the permissions allows to control the Bluetooth configuration to allow for more precision than devices usually are programmed to -- and physical activities control.
description: Website and also available as an app for download on Android; According to Fundación Karisma, it was initially developed to enforce lockdown, ideas was to connect it to police. Activates 34 permissions in phones.

title: SaludEC App: Ecuador symptom checker
description: In addition to offering self-assessment of symptoms and providing official information, this app allows you to schedule medical appointments for specialties not related to the coronavirus.
enforcement_details: To use the application, users must provide their name, year of birth, national identity document, phone number, e-mail, and geolocated address.

title: Estonia testing an immunity passport project
description: According to the project’s website: “The user can share information related to their immune status with a special QR code that can be shown to employers, friends, institutions, etc. Each QR code is unique and expires in one minute. Open access to data expires within an hour. This ensures that the state of immunity is up-to-date and protected against unauthorized sharing of sensitive health data.”
data_storage_details: Only the user, as the sole owner of their data, can share their data through the application.

title: Onfido in talks with European countries and US government to provide immunity passports
description: The British AI start up's founder said the company was in talks with various European countries and the US government about "playing a role" in immunity passport systems

title: Onfido in talks with UK government about immunity passports
description: Founder of Onfido told Politico he was in talks with the UK government about "immunity passports" which would allow people who have recovered from the coronavirus to prove their immunity and move freely, enabling lockdowns to end and economies to open up.

title: Tecuido: Honduras symptom checker & contact tracing
description:
The app, initially developed by the digital government, is no longer available in the Apple/ Google app stores. In May, there was backlash among civil society entities due to privacy concerns. 

The contact tracing app sought to generate a real-time epidemiological map based on contact tracing input.

notes.text: The government page that led to the app has been erased: http://www.conatel.gob.hn/index.php/2020/05/21/gobierno-digital-facilitara-la-vida-de-los-hondurenos-en-apertura-inteligente-de-la-actividad-economica/

title: Drones deployed to monitor lockdown enforcement in Croatian city of Rijeka
description: The Civil Protection Headquarters of the City of Rijeka has established surveillance of gatherings in public areas, especially playgrounds and beaches, with unmanned aerial vehicles of the Public Fire Brigade of the City of Rijeka

title: Drones deployed to monitor lockdown enforcement in Croatian city of Virovitica
description: Drones operated by the Croatian Mountain Rescue Service (HGSS) will also be involved in the fight against the spread of coronavirus in Virovitica. The drones will be used to monitor gatherings, to which authorities on the ground will respond

title: Rakning-19: Icelandic contact tracing app
data_storage_details:
Requests permission to track the user's location in the background. Geolocation updates are then stored on-device in a SQLite database. When the backend receives a request for data, it marks the user for data collection and triggers a push notification. Next time the user opens the app, it checks if there's a data request and allows the user to approve the request before sending 14 days of geolocation data to the backend.
The dataretention period is not known at the moment.

title: COVID-19MX: Mexico City's symptom checker website
description: The website contains a self-assessment questionnaire, information on hospital's capacities and location of COVID-19 test centres in Mexico City. In order to answer the questionnaire, users must provide personal information, including complete address.

notes.text: Launched in early April

In the privacy notice, the municipality says it will use the personal data collected for "the purpose of providing attention through social networks, online chat, SMS and telephone line, to those people who request the services of locating people lost, missing vehicles report, attention to the consumption of psychoactive substances; legal, medical, nutritional, psychological assistance, veterinary, as well as to provide information on procedures and services provided by the Public Administration of Mexico City."

data_storage_details: https://covid19.cdmx.gob.mx/resources/docs/aviso.extendido.pdf

title: New Zealand cell phone tracking for returning travellers
description: Travellers returning from abroad receive a text message asking them to consent to location tracking by the police. The police uses this information for quarantine and lockdown enforcement. If they consent, they should enable their location services on their cell phone.
enforcement_details: Voluntary but people can still be monitored via phone calls and random visits if they don’t consent to the mobile tracking.

title: Singapore starts distributing Bluetooth contact-tracing tokens to its five million residents
description: Like the app, the "tokens" use Bluetooth to look for other users' devices and then log any contact with those devices.
data_storage_details: According to the BBC: “Like app, information is stored on the token, purged regularly and is only uploaded - or in the case of the token physically handed over - to the Ministry of Health if the user tests positive.”

title: SafeEntry: Singapore introduces QR code system
description: The SafeEntry system is now being deployed in Singapore to try to speed up contact tracing. Where businesses and venues previously got people to fill in forms manually, this is a QR code that you have to scan, and then input your personal information and data before you enter.
enforcement_details: Voluntary for members of the public, mandatory for businesses
data_storage_details: The data is encrypted and stored on government servers. The government claims that only authorised personnel doing contact tracing can access the information, and that the information will be purged after contact tracing is no longer required (but there is no clear timeline given).

involved_organisations: Public Health Authority of the Slovak Republic
title: Slovakia amends telecoms law to track people in quarantine
description: Although the government backtracked on using metadata from calls and messages, the amendment still allows the country’s Public Health Office to have access to the location data stored by telcos.

title: eKarantena Slovensko: Slovak Quarantine app
description: The government is working to relaunch the app, retired in June, to be used to control the observance of mandatory quarantine for citizens coming from abroad. Local media was reporting it should be ready by April, but negotiations have apparently been suspended on March 17th (see link in note)

notes.text: The app was retired in June but the government told me it is ready to be relaunched, depending on the epidemiological situation.
https://www.teraz.sk/najnovsie/rokovanie-o-aplikacii-ekarantena-bolo/535561-clanok.html

title: SmartCity: Vietnam launches quarantine app
description: Patients [confirmed to have the virus] will be required to install the app on their phones. If they travel 20-30 metres from their homes or quarantine areas, the app will raise an alarm and send notifications to the residential clusters' heads and family members.

title: Police deploy drones in Limpopo
description: The drone broadcasts reminders about physical distancing, records and count people. "Officials monitor the footage and intervene if necessary. The first trial run resulted in an illegal shebeen being shut down.

title: Immuni: Italy launches contact tracing app
description: The app wwas released in four regions - Liguria, Abruzzo, Marche and Puglia - before being released to the whole country
data_storage_details: All data gathered by the app stay on the user’s phone unless the user tests positive and he decides to share her/his condition. If an app user tests positive can decide to upload this information on the app and this info will be transmitted to a main server in an encrypted and anonymous way.

related_legislations.details: On Apr. 17th, the Peruvian government published an amendment to its emergency law in which it authorizes a workgroup called 'Te Cuido Perú' to monitor people who report symptoms using geolocation data provided by telcos.
related_legislations.title: Decreto Supremo 070-2020-PCM

title: Perú launches geolocation monitoring for citizens who report symptoms
description: In Peru, the government has authorized the workgroup 'Te Cuido Perú' to use geolocation data provided by telecoms companies to monitor citizens (for three days) who have reported symptoms by calling an emergency number.

notes.text: The monitoring resulted from an amendment to the emergency law in Peru. The new decree was published on Apr. 17th
+ interview with Miguel Morachimo from Hiperderecho

title: Symptom track: Dutch Symptom Checker
description: Three Dutch companies have developed a symptom checker and heat map
data_storage_details: According to the website: "The entire questionnaire has been set up in such a way that we do not collect any personal data from you.

title: Peru launches Perusentusmanos
description: Not a big success.

involved_organisations: Vietnam Steering Committee for COVID-19 Prevention and Control
Vietnam Ministry of Information and Communications
title: NCOVI: Vietnam's symptom checker and heatmap
description: The health ministry’s official coronavirus app, NCOVI, enables users to log their symptoms and voluntarily report suspected infections in their area, identifying hot spots. It also gives advice on whether to self-quarantine or go to the hospital.

notes.text: According to the government website: https://english.mic.gov.vn/Pages/TinTuc/140775/Health-declaration-app-launched-in-support-of-COVID-19-combat.html

title: Paraguay's symptom checker open-data website

notes.text: Launched March 25th, according to Penguin House, one of the developers of the app: https://twitter.com/PenguinsTribe/status/1242813532833546241

data_storage_details: Users consent if they want to hand out personal information
description:
This project is an automated notification system, that allows individuals to report their symptoms and obtain recommendations on how to proceed, while also generating data from the situation.

In addition to the symptom-checker feature for citizens, this open-data platform developed by tech startups based in Paraguay seeks to collect statistics on the COVID pandemic in the country. The statistics are displayed in a tab inside the website, and there is also an information trivia that users can respond to.

title: KoviTrace: Kenya tracing app
description: The app, which can be installed on Android and IOS phones or accessed through USSD for users without smartphones, was developed by biochemist Donatus Njoroge, IT expert Gideon Kamau, and medical doctor Jesse Gitaki.

title: Kenyan university launches contact tracing app
description: Victoria Ngumi, vice chancellor of Jomo Kenyatta University of Agriculture and Technology (JKUAT), said that the application known as contact tracing and case management web and mobile application is meant to help identify who, where and when someone gets into contact with a COVID-19 patient.

title: Itoju: Nigeria Coronavirus app
description: A company representative told The Correspondent: “The app provides vital information to sensitize the general public about Covid19 and how best to protect themselves following the WHO guidelines. The app also serves as a reporting tool for citizens to ask for help or report any suspicious activities related to coronavirus for active community tracking. We noticed that the emergency response call line would be overwhelmed during this period, so we incorporated a chat system and distributed call setup to help optimize and complement the existing system by the NCDC. The app also features an active map with geolocation showing the spread of Covid19 in Nigeria both at the National and state level. However, to give people more access to the platform, we discontinued the mobile application and moved some of the features to a web platform in April 2020 - reportcorona.ng
data_storage_details: Anonymous data is stored for one week according to the company.

notes.text: When asked why the app was retired, a company representative told The Correspondent: “There is no issue with smartphone penetration in Nigeria, people don't just like to install apps on their smartphone especially if it is not essential to their lifestyle like financial services, social, etc.  People want to have information about the virus and other activities around it in a more convenient channel. They asked for it and we give them the website, they don't have to worry about installations or excessive mobile data consumption (which can also be a barrier at times in Nigeria).”

title: Boda Community: Ghana contact tracing website
description: Triage questions and contact tracing

title: Brazilian Hospital Albert Einstein launches self-assessment website
description: The Israelite Albert Einstein Hospital has launched the site autoavaliacaocoronavirus.einstein.br, which allows the public to answer a questionnaire and conduct a self-assessment online

title: "Coronavirusecuador.com" website
description: The website has the same function as the app, allowing users to directly call health authorities if they have COVID-19 symptoms and also has an option to schedule medical appointments on the website. The website also features a chatbot to answer questions.

notes.text: When the measure was first inputted, the website had a section dedicated to reporting false news circulating about the medical emergency, also according to Derechos Digitales. Now it has been removed from the site.

title: Alerta Honduras information and self-assessment app
SMS Covid19: Mexico City's SMS chatbot
description: By texting the word "covid19" to 51515, people in Mexico City can answers questions and find out what they should do in case they have symptoms. "If it is If necessary", the authorities will contact them "to receive due attention".

involved_organisations: The Agency for Electronic Government and the Information and Knowledge Society (Agesic) and the Ministry of Public Health of Uruguay (MSP)
title: Coronavirus UY: Uruguay's symptom checker and contact tracing app
description: Starting out as a self-assessment app, now CoronavirusUY also lets users activate “Exposure Alerts” to allow contact tracing, using the Google and Apple system

notes.text: Exposure tech launched in August but self-assessment app launched much earlier

data_storage_details: Decentralised

title: Mexico City tracks quarantined patients via telecoms data
description: On March 31, 2020, the Government of Mexico City announced that "Telephone companies will provide access to cell phone antennas so that, through the Digital Agency for Public Innovation (ADIP), monitoring of the movement and contact between people in Mexico City, with the aim of identifying if people are complying with the isolation ".

notes.text: Announced on March 31st

Red en Defensa de los Derechos Digitales, a civil society entity, published a note asking for more transparency on the government's part:

https://r3d.mx/wp-content/uploads/R3D-Comunicado_UsoDeTecnologia-COVID19.pdf?utm_campaign=meetedgar&utm_medium=social&utm_source=meetedgar.com

title: Simmov: App for authorities in Argentinian province of Jujuy
description: App designed so authorities can scan IDs in order to facilitate contact tracing, to track lockdown compliance and gauge citizens movements
data_storage_details: According to Diario Jujuy, the information collected is not stored on any mobile device; Rather, it is sent in an encrypted form to an exclusive database for this purpose and that complies with quality, backup, integrity and security standards. The database is hosted in Microsoft's cloud computing known as Azure, which also has the necessary security protocols to keep information safe and secure.
enforcement_details: The scan of one document (circulation permit) is mandatory, others are voluntary. The use of the app was temporarily halted by a judicial decision, but was resumed in July.

title: Cordoba's "Vecino Salud" app
description: Symptom checker and information app

title: Anglo American proposes contact tracing system for its SA mines
description: The company says it’s "too early to be specific" about how its system will work

title: Epione: South Africa symptom checker
description: South Africa's epione.net is piloting a symptom tracker, which allows users to request a screening if they meet case definition guidelines.

notes.text: Reported by Al Jazeera on Apr. 15th

title: Debo: Ethiopia contact tracing app
description: And an app called Debo captures the identity of anyone who comes within two meters of the user so that contacts can be traced should the person one day test positive.

title: COVID 19 Ethiopia: symptom checker app
description: The COVID-19 Ethiopia app was launched in late May so that the public can self-report cases or alert health authorities to others with symptoms.

title: Start-up introduces COVID-19 status verification software
description: Employees at Truework, an income verification start-up, will be asked to share their COVID-19 health data with their HR team. The employees will be required to submit information such as recent lab test results, and Truework may then verify that information with the lab itself.

title: PwC contact tracing
description: PwC, the professional services firm, is using technology that it originally developed to track inventory for a new contact-tracing system that logs employee interactions so workers can be notified in the event of exposure to the coronavirus.

title: KastleSafeSpaces system for offices
description: Businesses that use the company’s coronavirus management system, KastleSafeSpaces, may ask employees to download an app that will automatically open entrance doors for people eligible to come to the office. Workers who fill out a health screening questionnaire ahead of time may proceed to a lobby fast lane to have their temperatures checked. Those who have been asked to stay home because they recently tested positive for coronavirus may go on a kind of no-fly list and find that doors will automatically stay closed for them.

title: Clear's corporate "health pass"
description: Clear, the biometric identification company known for its air-traveler identification service, recently introduced a system called Health Pass for office buildings, restaurants, retailers, cruise ships and sports arenas. It will use facial recognition to confirm employees’ identities and vet worker-provided health information — such as symptom data and verified test results — so they can be cleared to enter workplaces.

notes.text: Reported by the New York Times on June 22nd

title: Microshare's wearable contact tracing system
description: Microshare, a software company in Philadelphia that uses sensors to monitor environmental factors — like indoor air quality and occupancy — for offices and manufacturing plants, is marketing a different kind of contact-tracing system. It is adapting Bluetooth technology that it originally developed to track the locations of wheelchairs and beds in hospitals for tracking employees. Employees will wear wristbands or carry credit card-size badges that collect signals about their whereabouts and proximity to one another; that data is sent to devices that transmit it to the cloud. Microshare said employers could also use its system to identify spots where infected workers may have recently gathered, enabling companies to shut down specific areas, rather than an entire building, for deep cleaning.

title: Verily health screening and analytics platform
description: The service, announced on Thursday, will offer Covid-19 diagnostic testing for employees and clear them to return to the workplace based on their test results and other health data. It will also make recommendations to employers on how often workers should be retested, based on the prevalence of the virus in their work force and the local community.

title: ProtectWell: Microsoft and UnitedHealth Group's symptom checking app
description: When staff at New York’s Natural History Museum were asked to enter their symptoms in the app, their Union filed an unfair labor practice complaint.
data_storage_details: According the Natural History Museum Union, the app’s data is not protected by Hipaa, the federal law on patient privacy.

notes.text: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/26/arts/design/natural-history-museum-coronavirus-app.html

title: Ready To Work: Fitbit symptom checker
description: Fitbit introduced a program that includes a daily symptom-checking app for employees and a work force health-monitoring dashboard for employers.

title: Kogniz AI workplace camera system
description: Kogniz, an artificial intelligence start-up, is marketing thermal camera systems as coronavirus fever-screening and "social-distancing enforcement" tools for the workplace.

title: AI start-up Jvion creates employer recovery package
description: Jvion, another A.I. start-up, is marketing an "employer recovery package" to predict the risk of employee exposure to the virus and likelihood of developing it.

title: PopID health screening at Subway restaurant
description: Owner of a Subway branch store in LA implemented temp. screening system. When workers stepped inside the employee food prep area, a fever-detection and facial recognition camera service, PopID, quickly identified him by name and gauged his temperature. Then a small tablet screen underneath the camera posted a message that cleared him to enter.

title: NBA "smart ring" health tracker
description: One optional tool the NBA is using for players within the bubble is the Oura smart ring, a wearable device that can measure skin temperature and heart rate, among other metrics. Oura is a lightweight metallic ring clad in sensors that enable the ring to measure metrics like your heart rate, skin temperature, and respiratory rate as well as your activity. It generates a risk score.

notes.text: Reported by CNN on June 24th
Reported in August: https://www.businessinsider.com/nba-bubble-oura-smart-ring-used-by-quarter-of-campus-2020-8?international=true&r=US&IR=T

title: Pegasystems app to track employees' Covid-19 exposure
description: Employees self-report their COVID-19 status via a short set of risk assessment questions. Their answers feed into the status dashboards and trigger a series of automated actions that guide affected employees, their managers, and human resources with instructions on how to manage their situation.

title: Cordata's Back-to-Work COVID Tracking System
description: The system includes "Assessment and tracking of individuals’ COVID-19 status, protocols and safety measures, including on-location contact-tracing".

title: Arcoro Includes COVID-19 Self-Screening Mobile Health Form in its Time Clock App
description:
The form asks employees two simple "yes or no" questions: first, whether they are experiencing symptoms such as fever, cough or shortness of breath; and second, whether they have been in contact with someone diagnosed with COVID-19 or have been told to self-isolate by a doctor or medical official.  

If the worker answers "yes" to either question, they are advised to leave the worksite and seek medical attention.

title: Appian's Covid-19 response system
description: The system includes "screening" as well as "investigatory contact tracing".

title: Estimote's "Proof of Health" wearable lanyards, wristwatches, or cards.
description: The wearable conducts GPS location tracking and Bluetooth contact tracing, and collected information is centrally stored and displayed on a health dashboard that "provides detailed logs of possible contacts.
data_storage_details: Centralised

title: Apple Watch adds function to track hand-washing

title: Chile's Covid-19 contagion maps
description: Chile's Ministry of Health (known as Minsal) keeps a georeferenced database, which is permanently updated, but which very few can access. Maps leaked to newspaper, reavealing location of Covid patients.

title: Chile's telecom companies confirm mobile mobility monitoring
description: Telecommunications companies operating in Chile confirmed that they are providing "aggregated and anonymous data on key mobility for public policies in the current pandemic.

title: Temperature screening in Chilean region
description: The mayor of Las Condes, Joaquin Lavín, said in a video, he plans to install cameras that take people's body temperatures in crowded places such as subway exits or bus stop.

title: Chilean region to use drones to enforce lockdown
description: The mayor of Las Condes, Joaquin Lavín, said drones would be used to tell people gathering in public places to return home

title: Tierra del Fuego's app: "TDFUnida
description: The government of the province of Tierra del Fuego launched the "TDFUnida" app in late April. The province established that people can only go out twice a week, for a maximum time of three hours each time, for example to go to the supermarket or the pharmacy. The TDFUnida app has a built-in self-diagnosis function to obtain the authorization to leave and travel. After its launch, criticisms of the application for its various security flaws and development errors were posted on Twitter.

notes.text: late April

title: Covid19 Jujuy
description: Symptom checker issued by Jujuy Province

involved_organisations: The Kansas Department of Health and Environment
title: Kansas uses Unacast data for anonymized phone tracking
description: Kansas is the first state to publicly acknowledge its use of such a program. Dr. Lee Norman, the head of the [health and environment] department, said that the state was using a platform called Unacast, which compares anonymized GPS data from before and after the implementation of social-distancing measures to track the measures’ effectiveness and offer county-level grades. Uses location data from other apps on a person's phone.

notes.text: Uses location data from other apps on a person's phone

title: India’s Nivida "Unlock 2020" system for workplaces
description: Merges employee attendance tracking with temperature log. A company representative told Vice the next step is to incorporate Bluetooth for contact tracing.

title: South Korea’s Epidemic Investigation Support System
description: A contact tracing platform that enables health officials to access location data and credit card transactions without a court order.

notes.text: Launched on March 21st according to Deutsche Welle: https://www.dw.com/en/south-koreans-offer-world-lessons-on-how-to-tame-coronavirus/a-55419719

Brookings: Even before the COVID-19 outbreak, the Korean government collected massive amounts of transaction data for investigating tax fraud. Literally every credit card and bank transaction in Korea is recorded on government databases. During the outbreak, this information was repurposed to retroactively track where people went: not just coffee shops and restaurants, but also buses and subways (the latter two mostly paid for by cashless tools).... In Korea, it is mandatory for companies to log the connections between towers and phones, making this information available to authorities.
Involved parties include: Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (KCDC), National Police Agency, the Credit Finance Association of Korea, Three telcos, 22 credit card companies

title: South Korea's tracking wristbands for people found to violate their quarantine terms
description: The Korean government announced plans to roll out location-tracking bracelets for people who break quarantine after reports of people tricking the government-mandated app by leaving their smartphones at home. The wristbands would instantly alert authorities if people tamper with them or cut them off. After backlash from human rights organizations, the government said the use of bracelets requires consent.

notes.text: Launched early April

A coalition of 17 human rights groups has expressed privacy concerns about the adoption of the tracking wristbands for people who violate quarantines, citing potential discrimination against patients. In response, the authorities have said that the wristbands would only be used if patients consent.

title: Self-Quarantine Safety Protection: South Korean quarantine app
description: All arrivals must download a government app that tracks their location and requires users to report any symptoms… After the two-week period, the app shows a message saying users are free to delete it from their phones.

title: Alibaba coronavirus diagnosis AI
description: A new AI-powered diagnosis system promises to detect new coronavirus cases with an accuracy rate of up to 96% via computerized tomography scans. The new diagnostic tool was first introduced in a hospital in Zhengzhou, Henan province and now the system will also be adopted in more than 100 hospitals in the provinces of Hubei, Guangdong and Anhui, said Alibaba.

title: Pwc's stress monitoring wearables
description: PwC UK has rolled out an AI wristband to its staff that monitors the wearer’s pulse, sleep and exercise patterns, and how they recover from heightened anxiety levels. Its aim is to understand how they are coping with stress during the lockdown.

title: Cadline’s iTWOsafe contact tracing system
description: Cadline’s iTWOsafe contact tracing system is a phone app which connects to a Bluetooth Low Energy device (BLE) worn as a wristband or attached to a uniform, that together track physical distance to other devices nearby. The system is great for employers; if an employee catches coronavirus traceable contact history can identify which other workers need to quarantine without closing the entire business, and it can also pinpoint where contacts take place, so a company can put in place extra measures, like a one way system.

notes.text: First orders shipped at the end of June

title: Soter Analytics' wearable contact tracing device
description: Soter used Bluetooth to develop a social distancing upgrade to its SoterSpine wearable device, a 2cm by 2cm and 20g black box. Clipped to a shirt or lanyard it alerts workers if they come within two metres of one another, to lessen the risk of contact. It also gathers data so at the end of the day it syncs detail of who has been in contact with who and for how long.

title: NHS announces partnership with Huma to remotely monitor patients with COVID-19 symptoms
description: Huma helping NHSX to create 'Virtual Wards' to monitor self-isolating patients with COVID-19 symptoms.

involved_organisations: The Center for Economic Policy Research
title: Spanish Spanish Think Tank tracking COVID using Bank Transaction DataCovid-Tracking with Bank Transaction Data
description: The Center for Economic Policy Research exploits high-frequency/high-resolution transaction data from BBVA, the second-largest bank in Spain, to analyse the dynamics of expenditure in Spain during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. This dataset provides the opportunity to study the impact of the ongoing crisis in Spain--and the policies put in place to control it--on a daily basis. Transaction metadata also allows the studying of variations in the expenditures across geography, sectors, and mode of sale (e.g. online/offline). Transaction data captures many salient patterns in how an economy reacts to shocks in real time, which makes its potential value to policy makers and researchers high.

notes.text: April 2020

involved_organisations: the Scottish Government and NHS Scotland.
title: COVID Symptom Study app
description: Large-scale symptom study by health science company ZOE and endorsed by the Welsh Government, NHS Wales, the Scottish Government and NHS Scotland. According to the project's website: "Participants have downloaded the app and are using it to regularly report on their health, making it the largest public science project of its kind anywhere in the world. App data is being analysed in collaboration with King's College London researchers.
data_storage_details: When we share data with researchers at partner institutions, such as Harvard University and Stanford University, it will be anonymised but as the USA has different rules on data protection they may not protect your data in the same way as, or as well as, under GDPR.

title: Beat Covid Gibraltar: Gibraltar’s contact tracing app
description: The Government, and I in particular, have zero interest in where you have been, whom you have been with and what you are doing," said Chief Minister Fabian Picardo.
data_storage_details: Decentralised

title: Hand-washing detector at Spanish hospital
description: One Barcelona, Spain, hospital is meanwhile testing a system that would require staff to wash their hands before unlocking doors to let them into patient rooms or intensive care units.

title: Digital health passports considered for football fans
description: Avi Lasarow, Prenetics’ chief executive for the EMEA region, told Reuters that digital health passports also offered the potential for eventually allowing matches to be played in front of spectators again. The digital health passport is a web-based platform that shows a person’s COVID-19 testing status and history by scanning a QR code to secure access to any venues where safety is a concern.

title: Teetamman: Saudi quarantine app
description: The Ministry of Health launched the app Teetamman, which collects health data for those who are in quarantine or self-isolation. People can use it to assess their health condition, speak to medical staff, and seek their advice. Recently, the app was made compulsory for those who are returning from abroad, and individuals are forced to wear a bracelet paired with the phone app via Bluetooth. The user must wear the bracelet at all times during the quarantine period, not change any of its settings, and keep the phone on for 24/7 hrs and within 10 meters proximity.
enforcement_details: Any attempt to remove or damage the bracelet or change any of these settings is punishable by up to two years in prison, a fine of 53,268 USD (200,000 Saudi Riyal), or both.

notes.text: First version on App Store on March 25th

title: Soapy hand-washing tracker

title: Western Australia purchases anklets with GPS tracking for monitoring people in quarantine

enforcement_details: Mandatory for people who had not “complied” with their quarantine order

title: PwC creating facial recognition tool

title: Siemens and Salesforce developing products to help companies get back to work.
description: Solutions will include "boarding passes’ for building and elevator entry, and a safe occupancy management system which will send warnings when room occupancy limits are reached.Employee check-in and contact tracing will also be available. Data will be collected many times per second using Siemens sensors, and delivered to workers and managers via apps.

title: Covid-19 Platform: A database designed to track people in quarantine, carry out contact tracing and identify large gatherings
description: According to Human Rights Watch, the platform amalgamates calls to the 171 emergency phone number, data from the Salud EC symptom checker app, information provided by cellphone service providers, satellite tracking and smartphones geolocation carried out by the ministry of telecommunications, as well as video surveillance via a nationwide camera system. Apparently, an algorithm is also used to detect the movement of cellphones between mobile phone antennas.

notes.text:
President Lenín Moreno tweeted about it on Apr. 13th
https://twitter.com/Lenin/status/1249458590387261446?s=20

title: Japan’s Fujitsu Ltd has developed an AI to monitor handwashing
description: Fujitsu’s AI can recognize complex hand movements and checks if people are completing a six-step hand washing procedure that asks people to clean their palms, wash their thumbs, between fingers and around their wrists, and scrub their fingernails. The AI can’t identify people from their hands but could be coupled with identity recognition technology so companies could keep track of employees’ washing habits, a company representative told Reuters. The AI was under development before the coronavirus outbreak for Japanese companies introducing stricter hygiene regulations, according to Fujitsu. It is based on crime surveillance technology.

related_legislations.details: MOS.RU: Decree of the Mayor of Moscow dated March 5, 2020 No. 12-UM established that patients with confirmed coronavirus infection undergoing treatment at home are required to use electronic geolocation monitoring technologies, including the Social Monitoring service.

title: Moscow's "Социальный мониторинг" or "Social Monitoring" quarantine app

However, users say they have been wrongly fined for leaving the apartment when they were taken to the hospital or others received penalties when their phones could not install the app because of technical limitations.
enforcement_details: Mandatory for patients under quarantine; subject to fines
data_storage_details: All data that the user transfers to the application is stored in a secure form on the servers of the Department of Information Technology. After treatment, these data are destroyed.

description: According to the developer: "An employee app, which is uniquely deployed as a chatbot across most popular chat applications (including WhatsApp, FB Messenger, etc. - full list on website) allows employees and visitors to screen themselves for COVID-19 symptoms remotely before they come into work. Those provisionally cleared for entry are sent a secure QR code valid for 24 hours. Those with symptoms are directed towards help including booking video calls with an assigned medical practice, and getting directions unto the latest NICD guidelines and company policies. Should the employee later be cleared by a COVID test, they can upload their clearance directly from the chatbot.”

title: CommonPass: global immunity passport

notes.text: https://www.weforum.org/videos/common-pass-travelling-the-world-in-the-covid-era

Already being used in travels to Aruba; in December, major airlines such as United, Lufthansa, Swiss, were set to adopt the app, according to reports: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/13/technology/coronavirus-vaccine-apps.html

data_storage_details: According to website, data is stored or shared only with explicit and informed consent. Personal identifiable health information is stored only at the source or on the user's phone. Data will be only stored to the extent necessary and not employed for other purposes.
description: CommonPass establishes partnerships with testing facilities. In order to travel, a person must get tested at one of the partner facilities. Then, the lab results will be sent straight to the app. The CommonPass platform assesses whether the individual’s lab test results or vaccination records (1) come from a trusted source, and (2) satisfy the health screening requirements of the country they want to enter. CommonPass delivers a simple yes/no answer as to whether the individual meets the current entry criteria, but the underlying health information stays in the individual’s control.

data_storage_details: Due to the use of blockchain technology, the data is completely anonymous.

title: Facial recognition cameras used to enforce Quarantine in Moscow
description: According to France24, "In Moscow, a network of 100,000 cameras equipped with facial recognition technology are being used to make sure anyone placed under quarantine stays off the streets. Russia is just one of several countries using high-tech surveillance in the battle against the coronavirus pandemic. The cameras are controlled from a purpose-built coronavirus control centre. Images and personal details of those under quarantine are put on a database so they can be recognised by the cameras.

notes.text: Reuters report mentions systems already in use Mid-March: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-russia-facial-reco-idUSKCN2253CM

title: Russia considering an app for migrant workers
description: According to HRW: “The reports said the app would contain, among other things, a migrant worker’s detailed biometric data, “health status,” and information on their police record. It is not clear from reports what ‘health status’ would include, nor was it clear what biometric information would be used — though in Russia this information could refer to height, weight, hair color, fingerprints, DNA analysis, retina images, facial recognition (photos and videos), and voice samples. Furthermore, the app would apparently note the person’s “social trustworthiness” rating. What a “social trustworthiness” rating is, what indicators are used to assign it or what it might be used for can only be speculated about at present, but it was suggested that refusal to install the app would result in a lowered rating.”
